articles.title: Sesame, a Conversational AI Startup From Oculus Founders, Launches Beta After Raising $250 Million
articles.author: TechCrunch
articles.fullContent:
Sesame, a Conversational AI Startup From Oculus Founders, Launches Beta After Raising $250 Million

Conversational AI startup Sesame has launched an early beta version of its iOS app after closing a $250 million Series B funding round. The company, founded by former Oculus CEO Brendan Iribe, aims to develop a personal AI agent that interacts with a natural human voice, with the ultimate goal of integration into lightweight smart glasses.

The funding round included major investors such as Sequoia Capital and Spark Capital. Sesame gained significant market interest after releasing two technical demonstration voices, “Maya” and “Miles,” which attracted approximately one million users in their first few weeks and generated over five million minutes of conversation. The company is developing its own hardware, bringing together core executives from the former Oculus team to create stylish AI-powered glasses.

“This experience is different from anything we’ve used before. The conversational layer of Sesame feels very different.” — Sequoia Capital

Data & Insights

The successful $250 million Series B funding round highlights strong investor confidence in the future of conversational AI and wearable technology. The beta app will initially allow users to test search, text, and thinking functionalities.

Broader Impact

Sesame is entering a competitive market but its focus on a vertically integrated system, combining emotionally intelligent voice agents with proprietary hardware, sets it apart. This approach could represent the next major shift in human-computer interaction, moving beyond touchscreens to more natural voice commands for daily tasks.

Key Takeaways

  • AI startup Sesame, from the founders of Oculus, raised $250 million in a Series B round.
  • The company launched an early beta of its iOS app for its conversational AI agent.
  • Sesame is developing both advanced AI voice software and proprietary smart glasses hardware.
  • The funding signals significant investor belief in voice as the next primary user interface.

articles.title: Veeam Acquires Data Security Company Securiti AI for $1.725 Billion
articles.author: SecurityWeek
articles.fullContent:
Veeam Acquires Data Security Company Securiti AI for $1.725 Billion

Data resilience provider Veeam Software has announced a definitive agreement to acquire data security posture management (DSPM) company Securiti AI for $1.725 billion in cash and stock. The acquisition is one of Veeam’s largest and marks its entry into the AI security market, aiming to unify data protection across production and backup environments.

The deal combines Veeam’s leadership in data backup and recovery with Securiti AI’s expertise in data governance, privacy, and compliance. This integration will provide enterprises with a single platform to manage, secure, and recover their data, which is critical for the safe deployment of artificial intelligence systems. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter.

“We’ve entered a new era for data. It’s no longer about just protecting data from cyber threats and unforeseen disasters; it’s also about identifying all your data, ensuring it’s governed and trusted to power AI transparently.” — Anand Eswaran, CEO at Veeam

Data & Insights

Securiti AI, founded in 2019, specialises in helping organisations manage data security across multi-cloud environments. Following the acquisition, Securiti AI’s CEO, Rehan Jalil, will join Veeam as President of Security and AI.

Broader Impact

This acquisition addresses a critical gap for enterprises that are struggling to launch AI initiatives safely. Many AI projects fail due to issues with data accuracy, governance, and permissions. By creating a unified command centre for all data, the combined company aims to help organisations understand and trust their data, mitigating risks and unlocking its value for AI innovation.

Key Takeaways

  • Veeam is acquiring Securiti AI for $1.725 billion to enhance its data security capabilities.
  • The deal combines Veeam’s data resilience with Securiti AI’s data security posture management (DSPM).
  • It aims to provide a single platform for data management, security, and recovery for enterprises deploying AI.
  • Securiti AI CEO Rehan Jalil will become Veeam’s President of Security and AI.

articles.title: Multimodal AI Startup Fal.ai Raises $250M at Over $4 Billion Valuation
articles.author: TechCrunch
articles.fullContent:
Multimodal AI Startup Fal.ai Raises $250M at Over $4 Billion Valuation

Multimodal AI infrastructure startup Fal.ai has reportedly secured approximately $250 million in a new funding round, pushing its valuation past $4 billion. The late-stage financing was led by prominent venture capital firms Kleiner Perkins and Sequoia Capital, reflecting surging investor demand for companies powering the next wave of AI applications.

This new valuation represents a significant increase for Fal.ai, which was valued at $1.5 billion just a few months prior during a $125 million Series C round. The company provides developers with cloud infrastructure for hosting and running over 600 image, video, and audio AI models, claiming to operate thousands of Nvidia H100 and H200 GPUs optimised for fast performance.

“Generative media is expanding faster than we ever imagined, and video is its next frontier. Fal has raised a $49M Series B to fuel our mission: building the core infrastructure for AI-driven media creation.” — Fal.ai Team (on a previous round)

Data & Insights

Fal.ai has seen explosive growth, with its revenue reportedly exceeding $95 million and its developer community growing to over 2 million users. This rapid expansion is driven by the high demand for multimodal AI capabilities, spurred by the popularity of video generation models like OpenAI’s Sora.

Broader Impact

The substantial funding for Fal.ai underscores the critical role of infrastructure providers in the booming generative AI ecosystem. As developers and enterprises race to build applications using complex AI models, platforms that offer optimised, scalable, and easy-to-use computational resources are becoming increasingly valuable.

Key Takeaways

  • Multimodal AI startup Fal.ai raised around $250 million in new funding.
  • The company’s valuation has surged to over $4 billion.
  • The round was co-led by Kleiner Perkins and Sequoia Capital.
  • Fal.ai provides the essential cloud infrastructure for running generative AI models for images, audio, and video.

articles.title: European AI Startup Nexos.ai, From Nord Security Founders, Raises €30 Million
articles.author: EU-Startups
articles.fullContent:
European AI Startup Nexos.ai, From Nord Security Founders, Raises €30 Million

Lithuanian startup Nexos.ai has raised €30 million in a Series A funding round to develop its enterprise AI adoption platform. The company, founded by the same team behind cybersecurity firm Nord Security, aims to help large organisations use AI tools safely and efficiently by managing governance, security, and costs.

The funding round was co-led by Evantic Capital and Index Ventures, with participation from Creandum and Dig Ventures. Nexos.ai is tackling the challenge of “Shadow AI,” where employees use consumer AI tools for work tasks, potentially uploading confidential data to public models without oversight. The platform acts as a neutral intermediary, or a “Switzerland for LLMs,” balancing productivity with enterprise-grade data control.

“Nexos.ai addresses the fundamental infrastructure gap preventing enterprises from capturing AI’s value while maintaining security control.” — Matt Miller, Evantic Capital

Data & Insights

The company provides a unified platform with two main products: an AI Workspace for employees and an AI Gateway for developers. The Gateway offers a single API endpoint for over 200 AI models from providers like OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic, with built-in security, routing, and cost management.

Broader Impact

As enterprises grapple with the risks of fragmented and unmonitored AI usage, platforms like Nexos.ai are becoming essential. By providing a secure and governed framework, they enable companies to innovate and experiment with AI confidently, ensuring compliance with privacy laws and internal policies. This trend mirrors the evolution of cloud computing, where security and cost governance became prerequisites for scaling.

Key Takeaways

  • Nexos.ai, from the founders of Nord Security, raised €30 million in a Series A round.
  • The platform helps enterprises adopt AI securely by managing governance, security, and costs.
  • It aims to solve the “Shadow AI” problem of employees using unsecured public AI tools.
  • The round was co-led by Evantic Capital and Index Ventures.

articles.title: Cloudflare CEO Urges UK Regulators to Address Google's AI Crawling Dominance
articles.author: The Tech Buzz
articles.fullContent:
Cloudflare CEO Urges UK Regulators to Address Google's AI Crawling Dominance

Cloudflare CEO Matthew Prince is lobbying UK regulators to force Google to separate its search and AI web crawlers, arguing that the current bundled system gives the search giant an unfair advantage in the artificial intelligence race. Prince met with the UK’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) to push for new rules that would promote equal footing among AI companies.

The core of the issue is that Google uses a combined crawler for both its search index and its AI model training. This forces website owners into an all-or-nothing choice: allow Google access for search traffic, which can account for a significant portion of revenue, or block the crawler entirely and lose that traffic, thereby also preventing their content from being used for AI training. This differs from competitors like OpenAI and Anthropic, who often have to pay for the content used to train their models.

Prince’s solution envisions thousands of AI companies competing to buy content from publishers and small businesses — a true marketplace rather than Google’s current take-it-or-leave-it approach. — The Tech Buzz

Data & Insights

The CMA recently designated Google with a special regulatory status due to its dominance in the search market. Prince argues that Google’s ability to harvest vast amounts of web content without payment, while its AI competitors must pay, creates an artificial barrier to competition in the AI sector.

Broader Impact

If UK authorities act on Cloudflare’s recommendations, it could set a significant global precedent. Such a move could reshape the AI industry by forcing a separation between search indexing and AI data collection, potentially creating a more competitive market for content licensing and influencing how other regulators approach the intersection of search dominance and AI development.

Key Takeaways

  • Cloudflare’s CEO is asking UK regulators to unbundle Google’s search and AI web crawlers.
  • He argues the current system gives Google an unfair data advantage for training its AI models.
  • Websites must choose between allowing access for search traffic or blocking Google’s AI training.
  • A regulatory change could create a more competitive market for AI training data and set a global precedent.

articles.title: Tutankhamun’s Tomb Faces Collapse Risk, Experts Warn
articles.author: The Independent
articles.fullContent:
Tutankhamun’s Tomb Faces Collapse Risk, Experts Warn

The 3,300-year-old tomb of Tutankhamun is in a dangerously fragile state and faces a significant risk of collapse due to widespread structural damage. Recent studies have identified spreading cracks, deteriorating rock from humidity, and fading murals, all of which threaten one of archaeology’s most important discoveries.

A major fracture running across the ceiling of the burial chamber has allowed rainwater to seep into the structure, dramatically increasing humidity levels. This moisture has accelerated fungal growth on the priceless wall paintings and weakened the tomb’s integrity. The tomb’s construction within unstable Esna shale rock, which expands and contracts with humidity changes, has exacerbated the damage.

“There are current and future risks that will affect the structural integrity of the tomb of Tutankhamun in the long term, and the tomb may not withstand for thousands of years in its current condition.” — Dr. Sayed Hemeda, Cairo University

Data & Insights

A catastrophic flash flood in the Valley of the Kings in 1994 marked a turning point for the tomb’s preservation. The event caused significant water ingress and triggered the fungal growth that continues to damage the murals today. Professor Sayed Hemeda of Cairo University identified this flood as a primary cause of the current structural weaknesses.

Broader Impact

The potential collapse of Tutankhamun’s tomb would be an irreplaceable loss for world heritage. Experts are calling for urgent conservation measures, including stabilising the internal climate and reinforcing the ceiling structure to prevent further deterioration and protect the iconic monument.

Key Takeaways

  • Tutankhamun’s tomb is at serious risk of collapse due to structural damage.
  • Key factors include a major ceiling fracture, water infiltration, and humidity.
  • The tomb was constructed in unstable Esna shale, making it vulnerable to moisture.
  • A major flood in 1994 is cited as a critical event that accelerated the decay.

articles.title: Netflix Signals Strong Commitment to Generative AI in Operations
articles.author: Mashable
articles.fullContent:
Netflix Signals Strong Commitment to Generative AI in Operations

Streaming giant Netflix is deepening its commitment to integrating generative AI, positioning the technology as a valuable tool to make content creation better and more efficient. The company recently confirmed the first use of final, on-screen generative AI footage in one of its original series and has published new guidelines for its creative partners regarding the use of AI tools.

In the Spanish-language series *The Eternaut*, AI was used to generate a complex visual effects sequence of a collapsing building in Buenos Aires. According to co-CEO Ted Sarandos, the sequence was completed ten times faster than with traditional methods and at a cost that would have otherwise been unfeasible for the show’s budget.

“We remain convinced that AI represents an incredible opportunity to help creators make films and series better, not just cheaper. This is real people doing real work with better tools.” — Ted Sarandos, co-CEO of Netflix

Data & Insights

Netflix has published new guidelines for its partners, outlining low-risk and high-risk use cases for AI. The company stresses that the use of AI should not replace work typically done by union-represented individuals without proper agreements and must respect creative rights and data privacy.

Broader Impact

As one of the world’s largest content producers, Netflix’s public embrace of generative AI sets a major precedent for the entertainment industry. While unions remain cautious, the company is framing AI as an assistive tool that enhances human creativity rather than replacing it. Netflix also plans to expand its use of AI in other areas, such as search functions and advertising.

Key Takeaways

  • Netflix has confirmed its first use of generative AI for final footage in an original series.
  • AI was used to create a VFX scene in *The Eternaut* ten times faster than traditional methods.
  • The company released new guidelines for partners on the responsible use of AI in production.
  • Netflix views AI as a creative aid to make content better, not just cheaper.

articles.title: Archaeologists Unearth Massive Ancient Roman Water Basin Near Rome
articles.author: Artnet News
articles.fullContent:
Archaeologists Unearth Massive Ancient Roman Water Basin Near Rome

Archaeologists have unearthed a massive, 2,200-year-old stone-lined water basin in the ancient Roman city of Gabii, approximately eleven miles east of Rome. Dating to around 250 BC, the structure is considered one of the earliest examples of Roman monumental architecture beyond temples and city walls, offering new insights into early Roman urban planning.

The discovery was made by a team led by Professor Marcello Mogetta from the University of Missouri. The basin was partly carved directly into the bedrock and was likely part of a monumental pool within the city’s forum, the centre of public and civic life. Its existence challenges the traditional narrative that early Roman architecture was modest before the conquest of Greece.

“This discovery gives us a rare look at how the early Romans experimented with city planning.” — Marcello Mogetta, University of Missouri

Data & Insights

The ancient city of Gabii was a rival to Rome that was largely abandoned by 50 BC. This abandonment left its original streets and foundations remarkably well-preserved, providing a clearer view of an early Roman city than is possible in Rome itself, where later construction has buried ancient layers. Italy’s Ministry of Culture has designated Gabii as an archaeological park.

Broader Impact

This finding helps reshape the understanding of early Roman civilisation, suggesting they were engaging in sophisticated, large-scale urban design earlier than previously thought. The ongoing excavations at Gabii continue to provide a unique window into the development of Roman engineering, architecture, and society.

Key Takeaways

  • A massive stone water basin from 250 BC has been discovered in the ancient Roman city of Gabii.
  • It is one of the earliest known examples of Roman monumental public architecture.
  • The discovery was made by a team from the University of Missouri.
  • Gabii’s exceptional preservation offers a rare glimpse into early Roman urban life.

articles.title: Perth Animal Shelters Overwhelmed by Unprecedented Number of Dog Surrenders
articles.author: PerthNow
articles.fullContent:
Perth Animal Shelters Overwhelmed by Unprecedented Number of Dog Surrenders

Animal shelters across Perth are reporting they are completely overwhelmed by a massive increase in dog surrenders, pushing their resources to the limit. The Dogs’ Refuge Home in Shenton Park has stated that the number of dogs coming into their care this year is higher than they have ever experienced before.

Other shelters, such as Swan Animal Haven, report a similar situation, with surrender requests at the highest level seen in 25 years of operation. As soon as a kennel becomes free, there is another dog on the waiting list to take its place, leaving staff unable to keep up with the demand and forced to turn many animals away.

“I’ve been doing this for about 25 years now and like it’s just never been this extreme. We’ve never had to turn away so many dogs.” — Jess Sackmann, President of Swan Animal Haven

Data & Insights

While national data suggests fewer animals have entered shelters in 2024-25, the situation in Perth appears to be bucking this trend. RSPCA WA noted a 15 per cent increase in voluntary surrenders, with owners citing lack of time, housing insecurity, and rising costs as the primary reasons for giving up their pets.

Broader Impact

The crisis highlights growing social and economic pressures on pet owners in Western Australia. The increase in surrenders places immense strain on the resources of non-profit shelters, which rely on donations and volunteers to care for the animals until new homes can be found.

Key Takeaways

  • Perth dog shelters are experiencing an unprecedented surge in surrendered animals.
  • The Dogs' Refuge Home in Shenton Park has reported record numbers of dogs in their care.
  • Reasons for surrender include housing insecurity and the rising cost of living.
  • The situation is placing significant pressure on shelter resources and capacity.

articles.title: Traces of Ancient Microbial Life on Mars May Be Preserved in Subsurface Ice
articles.author: Space.com
articles.fullContent:
Traces of Ancient Microbial Life on Mars May Be Preserved in Subsurface Ice

If microbial life ever existed on Mars, its biological traces could be preserved within the planet’s subsurface ice for tens of millions of years. A new study by NASA and Penn State University suggests that fragments of biomolecules, such as amino acids, could survive the harsh Martian radiation environment if trapped in pure water ice.

In laboratory experiments, researchers simulated Martian conditions by freezing E. coli bacteria in both pure ice and ice mixed with simulated Martian soil. They then exposed the samples to radiation levels equivalent to what they would experience over millions of years on Mars. The results showed that amino acids survived far better in pure ice compared to ice mixed with sediment, where they degraded almost completely.

“Fifty million years is far greater than the expected age for some current surface ice deposits on Mars, which are often less than two million years old, meaning any organic life present within the ice would be preserved.” — Christopher House, Penn State University

Data & Insights

The study challenges the view that organic materials cannot survive Mars’s intense surface radiation. In pure ice, harmful secondary particles generated by radiation are immobilised, reducing damage to trapped organic compounds. This makes regions of pure subsurface ice prime targets for future missions searching for signs of past life.

Broader Impact

These findings could significantly reshape the strategy for detecting life on Mars. Instead of focusing solely on complex rock or clay environments, future missions could be designed with tools capable of drilling into and analysing pure ice deposits. This provides a clear and accessible target that could increase the probability of discovering direct evidence of past life on the Red Planet.

Key Takeaways

  • A study suggests ancient microbial life on Mars could be preserved in subsurface ice.
  • Amino acids survived simulated Martian radiation for millions of years when trapped in pure ice.
  • Preservation was significantly lower in ice mixed with sediment, similar to Martian soil.
  • The findings suggest future Mars missions should target pure ice deposits to search for biosignatures.

articles.title: This Tiny Laser Could Transform How We See and Sense the World
articles.excerpt: Researchers have unveiled a compact, low-cost laser that outperforms current models in speed, control, and precision, with applications from Lidar to gas sensing.
articles.author: Norwegian University of Science and Technology
articles.fullContent:
A Next-Generation Laser on a Tiny Chip

Researchers from the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) and EPFL have developed a compact, low-cost laser that surpasses current models in speed, control, and precision. This next-generation laser is built using microchip technology, allowing for mass production and broad application in technologies ranging from Lidar navigation to gas detection. Its advanced stability and simple frequency tuning are set to transform communication and sensing technologies.

Traditional precision lasers are often bulky and expensive, but this new design overcomes these challenges. The laser is created with advanced materials and microscopic light circuits, enabling it to emit a powerful and stable beam. Users can adjust its frequency quickly and smoothly, a significant improvement over existing models.

"Our results can give us a new type of laser that is both fast, relatively cheap, powerful and easy to use," says Associate Professor Johann Riemensberger from NTNU.

The technology is particularly promising for self-driving cars, which use Lidar to map their surroundings by measuring light reflections. The new laser's precision can perform these measurements with an accuracy of approximately four centimetres. Because it is built on existing chip technology, it can be mass-produced cheaply, opening the door for more accessible and powerful sensing and communication tools.

Key Takeaways

  • A new compact, low-cost laser has been developed that offers superior speed, control, and precision.
  • Built on microchip technology, it is suitable for mass production and applications like Lidar and gas sensing.
  • The laser's design provides a stable beam and allows for easy and smooth frequency adjustments.
  • This innovation could make advanced sensing and communication technologies more affordable and user-friendly.

articles.title: 4th International Symposium on the History of Particle Physics
articles.excerpt: CERN is hosting the 4th International Symposium on the History of Particle Physics, focusing on the pivotal discoveries of the 1980s and 1990s.
articles.author: CERN
articles.fullContent:
Reflecting on a Transformative Era in Physics

From November 10-13, 2025, CERN will host the 4th International Symposium on the History of Particle Physics. This event will convene leading physicists, historians, and philosophers of science to discuss the significant breakthroughs and intellectual shifts that occurred during the 1980s and 1990s.

The symposium will place a special focus on the period when Europe, and particularly CERN, became the epicentre of particle physics research. This era saw major developments in theoretical, experimental, and accelerator physics. Discussions will also cover the growing integration of particle physics with cosmology and astrophysics.

A Legacy of Discovery

Following in the tradition of previous symposiums held at Fermilab and SLAC, this gathering aims to provide a comprehensive historical perspective on the science that probes the fundamental structure of the universe.

The event provides a crucial forum for reflecting on the scientific and technological advancements that have shaped our current understanding of fundamental particles and forces. It will examine the collaborative and competitive dynamics that drove the field forward during two of its most productive decades.

Key Takeaways

  • CERN will host the 4th International Symposium on the History of Particle Physics in November 2025.
  • The event will focus on the key discoveries and trends of the 1980s and 1990s.
  • It brings together physicists and historians to analyse a period when CERN was central to the field.
  • Topics will include theoretical, experimental, and accelerator physics, plus the links to cosmology.

articles.title: AI Update, October 17, 2025: AI News and Views From the Past Week
articles.excerpt: OpenAI is partnering with Walmart to bring instant checkout to ChatGPT, transforming the AI into a conversational shopping platform.
articles.author: Marketing Profs
articles.fullContent:
Conversational Commerce Revolution

OpenAI and Walmart are partnering to allow users to purchase products directly within ChatGPT, signalling a significant move into retail for the AI giant. This collaboration uses natural-language prompts to facilitate instant checkouts, effectively turning ChatGPT into a dynamic, conversational shopping platform and expanding OpenAI's commercial influence.

The integration of retail capabilities directly into chat environments is a strategic move by Walmart to leverage AI for a more seamless connection between product discovery and transaction. This development is poised to redefine key marketing metrics, including ad placement, content optimisation, and attribution, as commerce becomes increasingly AI-driven.

"Marketers should watch how conversational commerce changes product discovery and conversion."

In parallel, Slack is enhancing its platform by transforming Slackbot into a personalised AI assistant capable of answering queries, summarising channels, and coordinating projects. Salesforce is already piloting this AI-enhanced Slackbot with its 70,000 employees, indicating a strong enterprise demand for integrated AI workspace companions. The broader rollout is anticipated by the end of the year and promises to streamline internal collaboration and automate routine tasks for marketing teams.

AI's Expanding Role

Other significant developments this week include the deployment of generative AI agents in Indian call centres, which now handle up to 80% of customer interactions, and a lawsuit against Apple alleging the use of copyrighted books to train its Apple Intelligence system. These events highlight the rapid and sometimes controversial expansion of AI into various sectors.

Key Takeaways

  • OpenAI's partnership with Walmart introduces direct shopping and checkout within ChatGPT.
  • Slack is testing an AI-powered assistant to automate project management and streamline workflows.
  • The shift towards AI-driven automation is accelerating, impacting customer service and raising copyright concerns.
  • Marketers must adapt to new forms of conversational commerce and AI-powered workspace tools.

articles.title: Quantum Networks Bring New Precision to Dark Matter Searches
articles.excerpt: Researchers propose using carefully designed quantum sensor networks to boost sensitivity in the search for dark matter, one of the greatest unsolved problems in physics.
articles.author: Tohoku University
articles.fullContent:
A New Frontier in Detecting the Unseen

Scientists at Tohoku University have proposed a revolutionary method to enhance the search for dark matter by connecting highly sensitive quantum sensors into optimised networks. Detecting the faint signals from this mysterious substance, which is believed to hold galaxies together, has been a major challenge in physics. This new approach could finally make it possible to capture the elusive clues left by dark matter.

The study centres on superconducting qubits, which are tiny, super-cooled electric circuits typically used in quantum computers. By linking these qubits, which act as powerful quantum sensors, the network can function as a single, super-sensitive detector. This collective arrangement allows for the detection of weak signals far more effectively than any individual sensor could achieve on its own, leveraging the principles of quantum entanglement.

"Our goal was to figure out how to organize and fine-tune quantum sensors so they can detect dark matter more reliably," stated Dr. Le Bin Ho, the study's lead author.

Broader Technological Implications

Beyond the search for dark matter, these advanced quantum sensor networks have the potential to revolutionise other fields. Potential applications include the development of quantum radar, more precise gravitational wave detection, and ultra-accurate timekeeping. Dr. Ho added that this research opens the door to using quantum sensors in real-world tools that require extreme sensitivity, such as improving GPS accuracy and enhancing MRI brain imaging.

Key Takeaways

  • Researchers propose using quantum networks of superconducting qubits to significantly increase sensitivity in dark matter detection.
  • Quantum entanglement allows the network to act as a single, highly effective detector, filtering out noise and amplifying faint signals.
  • The technology has wide-ranging applications beyond physics, including advancements in GPS, MRI, and gravitational wave detection.
  • The findings were published in the journal Physical Review D.

articles.title: New Data Release From CUORE Features A 'Noise-Canceling' Algorithm
articles.excerpt: The CUORE experiment, the coldest cubic meter in the known universe, is using a new algorithm to filter out background noise in its search for a rare nuclear process.
articles.author: Interactions.org
articles.fullContent:
Refining the Search for Matter's Origin

The Cryogenic Underground Observatory for Rare Events (CUORE) has released new data incorporating a sophisticated “noise-canceling” algorithm to improve its search for neutrinoless double beta decay. This rare nuclear process could help explain why the universe is composed primarily of matter. The new technique allows scientists to better filter out distracting background signals from vibrations and other sources.

With a dataset now double the size of what was previously published, the CUORE collaboration has established new, stringent limits on the occurrence of this decay in tellurium atoms. The findings, published in the journal *Science*, suggest the event happens no more than once every 50 septillion years on average. The experiment uses 988 tellurium dioxide crystals cooled to just 10 millikelvin, making it the coldest cubic meter in the universe.

"The focus of this data release is understanding sources of external vibrations and learning how to subtract that from our data to better search for this extremely rare decay," said Reina Maruyama, U.S. spokesperson for CUORE.

The new noise-subtraction techniques are not only pivotal for CUORE but could also benefit other highly sensitive detectors, including those used in dark matter and gravitational wave research. This advancement is also crucial for the next-generation experiment, CUPID (CUORE Upgrade with Particle IDentification), which will continue the search with even greater precision.

Key Takeaways

  • CUORE has implemented a new algorithm to cancel background noise, enhancing its search for a rare nuclear decay.
  • The experiment has set a new limit for neutrinoless double beta decay: occurring no more than once every 50 septillion years.
  • This technological advancement has potential applications for dark matter and gravitational wave experiments.
  • The results are based on the largest dataset of its kind from a solid-state detector, weighing approximately 0.8 tonnes.

articles.title: Mistress Kanan Is Devilishly Easy Anime Unveils First Trailer and Visual
articles.excerpt: A new trailer and visual have been released for the upcoming anime adaptation of Mistress Kanan is Devilishly Easy.
articles.author: Anime Corner
articles.fullContent:
New Anime Adaptation Announced

An anime adaptation for the manga 'Mistress Kanan is Devilishly Easy' (Kanan-sama wa Akumade Choroi) has been announced, with a new key visual and main voice cast revealed. The series is scheduled to premiere in 2026 and will be animated by Studio KAI. The main cast will feature Aoi Koga as Kanan Takakiyo and Seiichiro Yamashita as Yoji Kyogi.

The story follows Kanan, a demon who goes undercover in a human high school to prey on souls. She targets a specific male student, but unexpectedly ends up in a romantic contract with him. Having never experienced love, Kanan is overwhelmed by these new and unfamiliar emotions, leading to a comedic and sweet romantic comedy.

"Even during the audition, Kanan-sama was expressing such a wide range of emotions that I thought, 'She's so fun and cute to play!' I'm truly happy to have been chosen for the role," said Aoi Koga, the voice of Kanan.

The original manga, written and drawn by nonco, has been serialised in Kodansha's Weekly Shonen Magazine since June 2022. The announcement of the anime adaptation has been met with excitement from fans of the manga, who are eager to see the characters brought to life.

Key Takeaways

  • An anime adaptation of 'Mistress Kanan is Devilishly Easy' is set to premiere in 2026, animated by Studio KAI.
  • The main voice cast includes Aoi Koga as Kanan and Seiichiro Yamashita as Yoji.
  • The story is a romantic comedy about a demon who falls in love for the first time while trying to harvest souls in a high school.
  • The original manga has been running in Weekly Shonen Magazine since 2022.

articles.title: How 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics Led to the 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics
articles.excerpt: A look at the scientific background and historical context of the 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics, awarded for the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunneling.
articles.author: IYQ 2025
articles.fullContent:
Celebrating a Milestone in Quantum Science

The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret, and John M. Martinis for their pioneering discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunneling and energy quantization in electrical circuits. This award recognizes a significant achievement in quantum science and technology, aligning with the United Nations' designation of 2025 as the International Year of Quantum Science and Technology.

Quantum tunneling describes the ability of a particle to pass through a potential energy barrier that it classically should not be able to overcome. The laureates' work demonstrated that this phenomenon is not limited to microscopic particles but can be observed in large systems, or 'macroscopic' objects, comprising many thousands of electrons acting as a single entity. Their experiments with ultrathin superconducting wires showed that a whole collection of superconducting electrons could 'tunnel' from a state of higher electrical current to a lower one.

This research provides further evidence that the laws of quantum mechanics continue to govern large systems.

The historical context for this discovery dates back to the early 20th century with Max Planck's introduction of energy quantization and Albert Einstein's explanation of the photoelectric effect, which proposed that light is made of discrete packets of energy called photons. These foundational ideas revolutionised physics and paved the way for understanding the quantum nature of our world, from the bonds holding atoms together to the behaviour of complex materials.

Key Takeaways

  • The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunneling.
  • The winners are John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret, and John M. Martinis.
  • Their work showed that large collections of electrons in superconducting circuits can exhibit quantum tunneling, a behaviour previously thought to be limited to single particles.
  • The discovery builds on a century of quantum mechanics research, from Planck's energy quanta to modern quantum technology.

articles.title: Jaromir Malek Memorial Lecture 2025
articles.excerpt: The second lecture in memory of esteemed Egyptologist Dr Jaromir Malek will be delivered by Professor Tony Leahy at Queen's College, Oxford.
articles.author: Griffith Institute
articles.fullContent:
Honouring a Legacy in Egyptology

The Griffith Institute has announced the second memorial lecture for Dr Jaromir Malek (1943-2023), scheduled for the evening of Thursday, 16 October 2025. The event will take place at the Shulman Auditorium in Queen's College, Oxford, and will feature a presentation by Professor Tony Leahy.

Professor Leahy's lecture is titled "Questions of provenance: accommodating uncertainty in a topographical work of reference." The talk is scheduled to begin at 5pm BST and will be followed by a drinks reception. This event provides an opportunity for scholars and the public to engage with key issues in Egyptological research while commemorating Dr Malek's significant contributions to the field.

The Griffith Institute, based at the University of Oxford, is a central hub for Egyptology and Ancient Near Eastern Studies. It is home to major research projects and houses an extensive archive that includes the records of Howard Carter's discovery of Tutankhamun's tomb.

Event Details

The lecture is a free event, and all interested parties are welcome to attend. Registration is required via Eventbrite to secure a place.

Key Takeaways

  • The second Jaromir Malek Memorial Lecture will be held on October 16, 2025, at Queen's College, Oxford.
  • Professor Tony Leahy will deliver the lecture, titled "Questions of provenance: accommodating uncertainty in a topographical work of reference."
  • The event is free and open to the public, with registration available through Eventbrite.
  • The lecture honours the memory and contributions of the distinguished Egyptologist Dr Jaromir Malek.

articles.title: Earth and Environmental Sciences News Roundup
articles.excerpt: Recent developments from the University of Pennsylvania's Earth and Environmental Science department include awards for distinguished professors and new research on climate change.
articles.author: University of Pennsylvania
articles.fullContent:
Climate Week and Faculty Honours

The University of Pennsylvania is hosting its sixth annual Climate Week from October 13-17, 2025, with this year's theme being “Hot Spots.” The week features a series of events aimed at engaging the community on the climate crisis, including the 1.5* Minute Climate Lectures and a conversation between Michael Mann, Director of the Penn Center for Science, Sustainability and the Media, and Bill Nye.

In faculty news, President's Distinguished Professor Joseph Francisco was awarded the 2025 Pauling Medal. Separately, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation announced its 2025 class of Packard Fellows, which includes Dohyung Kim from Penn's Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering. The fellowship provides $875,000 over five years for early-career scientists to pursue their research.

Research Highlights from Penn State

Meanwhile, researchers at Penn State have been active. One study revealed that Earth's continents stabilised due to furnace-like heat in the planet's early history. Another Penn State study suggests that if microbial life exists on Mars, its remains could be preserved in the planet's ice deposits. The research found that organic materials in pure ice are destroyed at a much slower rate than when mixed with soil, making icy regions ideal for searching for signs of life.

Student Innovation

At Penn's Climate Week, a “Shark Tank”—style competition called Transform Penn will allow students to pitch ideas for improving campus sustainability. Winners will receive mentorship and funding to implement their projects through the Penn Sustainability Green Fund.

Key Takeaways

  • The University of Pennsylvania's Climate Week runs from October 13-17, focusing on climate action and education.
  • Professor Joseph Francisco has been awarded the 2025 Pauling Medal.
  • Penn State research provides new insights into the formation of Earth's continents and the potential for preserving biosignatures on Mars.
  • Penn's Dohyung Kim was named a 2025 Packard Fellow in Science and Engineering.

articles.title: Scientists Create a Paper-thin Light That Glows Like the Sun
articles.excerpt: Researchers have developed a revolutionary ultra-thin quantum dot LED that can replicate the full spectrum of natural sunlight, improving colour accuracy and reducing eye strain.
articles.author: American Chemical Society
articles.fullContent:
A Breakthrough in Lighting Technology

Scientists have engineered an LED that is nearly as thin as a sheet of paper and emits a cozy, sunlike glow. This innovation, detailed in the journal *ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces*, promises to revolutionise lighting in homes, devices, and workplaces by providing a quality of light that is remarkably close to natural sunlight.

The new design relies on a carefully engineered balance of red, yellow-green, and blue quantum dots. By synthesising quantum dots coated with zinc-sulfur shells and determining the precise ratio needed, the researchers successfully recreated the balanced spectrum of sunlight. This achievement not only improves colour accuracy in artificial lighting but also helps reduce the eye strain and sleep disruption often caused by harsh artificial lights.

This new design could illuminate the future of phone and computer screens as well as other lighting applications.

The development team combined expertise in quantum dots with an efficient conductive material design, allowing the ultra-thin white quantum dot LED (QLED) to operate effectively at low voltages. This efficiency makes the technology a viable candidate for future applications in a wide range of electronic devices and general lighting solutions.

Key Takeaways

  • Scientists have created an ultra-thin, paper-like LED using quantum dot technology.
  • The LED replicates the full spectrum of natural sunlight, which can reduce eye strain.
  • The innovation was achieved by balancing red, yellow-green, and blue quantum dots.
  • This technology could transform screens for devices like phones and computers, as well as general home and workplace lighting.

articles.title: Battlefield 6 Does Not Include Content Made by Generative AI, Says EA
articles.excerpt: Ahead of the launch of Battlefield 6, Electronic Arts has stated that players will not encounter any content created by generative AI in the new game.
articles.author: Gadgets 360
articles.fullContent:
EA Confirms No Generative AI in Final Game

Electronic Arts has confirmed that the newly launched Battlefield 6 does not contain any content created by generative AI. The statement came ahead of the game's release on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series S/X, addressing recent industry and consumer discussions around the use of AI in game development.

Rebecka Coutaz, a VP general manager at one of the studios involved, explained that while generative AI was utilised in the very early preparatory stages to help the team be more creative, it was not used to create content for the final product. This clarification comes as the games industry grapples with resistance from creatives and consumers regarding generative AI, even as investors see potential for cost-cutting.

Coutaz described the technology as "very seducing" but noted that a clear way to incorporate it into development workflows is not yet established.

The announcement also arrives shortly after EA revealed a major buyout deal to take the company private, with investors reportedly interested in the cost-saving potential of increased AI usage. Despite this, for its biggest launch in franchise history, EA has maintained a traditional development approach for in-game content.

Key Takeaways

  • Electronic Arts stated that no generative AI-created content is present in the final version of Battlefield 6.
  • AI was used during early ideation phases to foster creativity but not for final asset production.
  • An EA executive called the technology "very seducing" but acknowledged challenges in its implementation.
  • The clarification addresses concerns from creatives and players about the role of generative AI in game development.
